datafield.subfield: Oakland Army Base Oral History Project ; interviews conducted by Martin Meeker in 2007. Regional Oral History Office, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley.

After serving in the Navy, Billups became an electrician at the Oakland Army Base, working as a civilian employee of the Department of Defense. He retired from this position in 1997. In this interview, Billups discusses his work at the base as well as his thoughts on the Vietnam War and changing social relations over the course of his career.

Oral history is a method of collecting historical information through recorded interviews between a narrator with firsthand knowledge of historically significant events and a well-informed interviewer, with the goal of preserving substantive additions to the historical record. Because it is primary material, oral history is not intended to present the final, verified, or complete narrative of events. It is a spoken account. It reflects personal opinion offered by the interviewee in response to questioning, and as such it is partisan, deeply involved, and irreplaceable.

Literary rights in the manuscript, including the right to publish, are typically reserved to The Bancroft Library of the University of California, Berkeley, but in some cases are retained by third parties.

Please see the information at the beginning of each transcript regarding permission information. For more information on permissions please see: http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/libraries/bancroft-library/oral-history-center/rights.
Bancroft Library. Regional Oral History Office.
Oakland Army Base Oral History Project.
Richard Billups: Oakland Army Base Oral History Project
Billups, Richard. "Richard Billups: Oakland Army Base Oral History Project." Interview by Martin Meeker in 2007. Oral History Center, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, 2009.

Richard Billups was born in 1943 and raised in Oregon. After serving in the Navy, Billups became an electrician at the OAB, working as a civilian employee of the Department of Defense. He retired from this position in 1997. In this interview, Billups discussed his work at the base as well as his thoughts on the Vietnam War and changing social relations over the course of his career.
